DOC.HEAD: Cyprus Party Chief Denies More Resignations Imminent
DOC.TEXT: The secretary-general of the powerful Cyprus Communist Party denied Tuesday that the party is opposed to perestroika and said none of its hard-line old guard intends to resign. The statement came one day after the resignation of Michael Papapetrou, a leading reformer in the party, which is known as Akel. Papapetrou, 42, also resigned from Parliament, where he had been a member since 1985. Papapetrou complained that most of Akel's Central Committee did not support perestroika _ the political and economic restructuring sought by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. His statement came at the end of a five-day Central Committee meeting. Dissenters have accused the party of sticking to discredited Stalinist methods. Papapetrou said the discussion ``indicated that the Central Committee does not have the slightest intention to compromise ... opening the way for reform and perestroika.'' Demetris Christofias, 43, Akel's secretary-general, told a news conference Papapetrou's resignation saddened him and the two would meet to discuss the issues Papapetrou raised. ``We will proceed with the renewal of the party as decided by the Central Committee meeting and will implement the message of perestroika and new thinking...,'' he added. A statement issued after the Central Committee meeting condemned the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia, falling in line with East bloc parties. Papapetrou and other reformers had publicly criticized the party for stalling on such a denunciation. Christofias reacted angrily when asked if any old-guard members of the 75-member committee, aged over 70, would resign in recognition of past mistakes. ``We are proud and honor and respect the older members of our committee who have spent a lifetime in the service of the working class and who have nothing to be ashamed of,'' he said.
